39438281.review:
While a bit brutal at times, Full Metal Furies is a really enjoyable co-op romp. I've only played two-player so far, but found the whole experience extremely compelling. It gets super hard at times, so be prepared to die... a lot. There is an easier difficulty, but I haven't bothered with it yet.

Luckily there's a whole host of upgrade mechanics to smooth out the difficulty curve, from a Rogue Legacy style leveling system unique to each character, to passive usage-based stat gains, to a skill customization system with a lot of fun variance. It's rare to find a beat-em-up with this level of customization, and I really appreciate it in this game.

The art's also completely gorgeous, and the soundtrack is superb.

One word of warning: the netcode might be a bit dodgy. Check recent reviews to see if they've fixed the issue yet.

Overall, if you've got a couch full of friends and have been looking for a good alternative to Castle Crashers, Full Metal Furies is 100% worth a look.

39434824.review:
I really like the character art and animations, the time put into designing skill trees and upgrades. There is nice music and all female cast feels refreshing. I also liked the idea of color shielding enemies, but it kinda backfires when one player of certain colour is down and rest gets smacked down because they can't hurt the enemies or revive a friend in timely manner. 

You can tell a lot of work and heart went into making of this game. Unfortunately gameplay is frustrating and not well balanced. I've played in single player mode as well as 4 player co-op, and after finishing first map (5ish levels + a boss fight) noone wanted to play anymore.  

The gameplay is based on canceling abilities/attacks and making combos with other players (i.e. one throws enemy into the air and the second on shoots him down for an Air Crit attack), which works well in theory, but it's hard to coordinate those actions due to weird timing of the cooldowns. Sometimes it makes dodging enemies impossible and some characters feel super unresponsive. Maybe it's the lack of input buffering or something like that.In example if a few enraged enemies target your character there is now way to dodge them or avoid the attack. 

Aiming with the sniper would use aim snap or something like that since with very sensitive gamepad there is no way to be super precise across the entire screen and make a shot before other character's attack blows the enemies all over the place. 

Level design is uinteresting and unrewarding - each level is pretty much the same with few encounters and a frustrating enviro damage section or "the foreground covers entire screen" section. Scrolling "bullet hell" sections don't work great if camera bounds are blocking the player movement. If one player is at the bottom of the screen and he dies, he stops all the others at the top - and in those sections this means entire squad dies and you have to replay it all over again. Also if the readibility of the game isn't great (lot of characters, a lot of actions) please don't add the show covering additional parts of the screen or foreground elements. 

There are "secrets" hidden on the levels but nobody really cared about those. The same with the story - game is just covered in dialogues and it doesn't fit the frantic gameplay at all. There is an opition in the menu to disable the non-essential dialogues tho, which is a plus. 

Game HuB is interesting, and works well in the single player mode, but for few players at the same time it's just a giant mess - the upgrade screens clutter the screen, not everything can be upgraded (some actions may be performed by every player, some only by game's Host), but even tho all players have access to the screens which do nothing but clutter the screen. 

I guess having full-resolution backgrounds and pixel art characters and destructibles was readibility choice, but in full HD all menus and backgrounds are pixelated anyway. Sometimes it's hard to tell which elements are destructible and which aren't. You should be able to destroy low-res objects, but there are some high-res walls which you need to destroy that doesn't stand out of the environment at all. Readibility of the characters is poor and with a lot of enemies on screen it's hard to see who is where and it makes it very hard to dodge the attacks or bullets. 

There is some fun to be had in the game and I think it has potential, but in my opinion it needs a lot of work on the gamefeel and usability before I could recommend it to anyone.

39433338.review:
Rogue Legacy is one of my all-time favourites - Full Metal Furies has a lot to live up to.

Pleasingly, FMF feels absolutely brilliant. Playing solely in single-player so far, chaining combos with the different characters is exhilerating, and early indications suggest there is a high skill ceiling to strive for.

I have not yet tried multiplayer, but considering I will likely only play locally, the current network issues will not impact my experience.

Like Rogue Legacy, Full Metal Furies features a great soundtrack to punctuate the action. Buying the tunes on Bandcamp was an absolute no-brainer.

The only negative is the lack of visual clarity when displayed in 1920x1080. This makes reading the text a bit uncomfortable. While the pixel-art style masks the slightly blurred visuals, FMF would be even greater with an extra layer of sharpness.

Above all else, FMF features great action, an awesome soundtrack, and delightfully silly writing - I'll be playing Cellar Door Games' brilliant Rogue Legacy follow-up, Full Metal Furies, for hours.

39424104.review:
This is very much a recommendation in progress.

This game scratches an itch I didn't know I had. The writing is brisk, clever, and fun. The gameplay is tight and engaging, and the design of the game is one of enthusiastic cooperation, even if you're playing by yourself. From Ikaruga style color swapping between characters in singleplayer to team tactics in multiplayer, the game doesn't disappoint on the application of its "gimick". Couple the unique flavor and cool world design with the crunchy, satisfying gameplay mechanics and you have a strong game, made better by its progression system which doles out just enough to encourage trying new playstyles without feeling like the core of the gameplay is getting smothered under farming or completion hunting. I have no complaints about this game other than the UI being a bit distorted looking (may be intentional, but it's a little bit jarring) and that some levels have inconsistent difficulty and length in unexpected ways. However, the game is a shining example of getting the basics right and building upward, and I look forward to not only my solo run, but picking up and playing with friends in the future.

39421359.review:
Full Metal Furies delievered what was promised: A new kind of brawler. It's missing many of the minor annoyances of the genre. However, it is much more difficult then some i've played, though ultimately, I'd guess, more forgiving then Cellar Door's previous title, Rogue Legacy. The RPG-style upgrade system certainly helps, as does the fact that you keep all gold obtained in levels- even that obtained during boss fights, as they drop gold whenever they reach a health threshold. Good stuff. Still, towards the end it started feeling rather unfair. If my friend had not  mastered Triss in just a few short sessions, I doubt I would have gotten far. As it is, I was most comfortable using Meg.

The game's asethetic is absolutely spon on. It has great music, lovely background art and great character designs, and also surprisingly entertaining writing. Triss' being done with everything, Alex's unabashed enthusiasm, Erin's need to educate her less well-read companions, and Meg's state of only partial wakeness and interest. They're all endearing. In addition, there is a deeper subgame involving the finding of ancient tablets and the solving of riddles I was curious to see where this went, but it eventually proved beyond my puzzling abilities to solve, as several of them require out of the box thinking and bring you to conclusions I could not possibly have drawn on my own. Again, my friend had to step in.

Still, unlike say, Shovel Knight's DLC campaigns, or Cave Story's true ending path, Furies did not leave a bad taste in my mouth the way a lot of frustrating games do. I owe this to its presentation- it feels like reaching the end of a journey. As a kid who grew up reading of the Greek myths and enjoying beat em ups, Furies has a comforting familiarity to it.

There's a nifty ability to switch between two characters if you're playing solo, and mechanics that both make it easier to see whats happening and to encourage teamplay and coordination, like color-coded shields that only the corresponding character can break. It seems to have some issues with resolution- I've played with the graphics settings and its always a bit fuzzy. It also didn't seem to work with the Steam overlay at launch, though this appears to have been fixed. Also, aiming Meg's riflle with a 360 controller feels a tad awkward. But it's definitely playable. If you've been eagerly anticipating this title like me, and enjoy Beat-Em-Ups or Action-RPGs, go ahead and grab it now that its out. 

As an end note, this game has already been heavily patched and Cellar Door seems to have a great deal of concern for it and its players, which is more then you can say for a lot of games.

39418681.review:
Watch us play this game for the first time @ Spinning Wizard! - https://youtu.be/idGnEDpsMb8

Full Metal Furies is a 1 to 4 Player Adventure-Beat'emup with RPG elements, controlling the Furies; an all girl squad.
With fast paced action and extremely tight controls, this game is extremely enjoyable and brutally hard.
Four characters to choose from, ranging from melee to sniper, all with diverse skills and easy to pickup but tough to master.
The art style is great, blocky retro characters over crisp hi-res cartoon backgrounds. A genuinely comedic storyline and packed with charm and character.

Similar to Rogue Legacy (CellarDoors previous hit), the different enemies all have simple identifiable movesets and attack patterns. But the skill comes in fighting any combination of hordes of them at once!

We've had so much fun playing this so far, the game had us swearing with anger as it is consistently tough; but we never felt conned or ripped off. This led to us wanting just one more go. And another.

If you like your games hard, have a band of friends that like to cooperate, love the retro appeal or just fancy something different, this wont dissappoint.

This will be a future classic.. would love to see a physical release on switch .. wink wink.

Ben @ Spinning Wizard

Sidenote: despite running rx580s in crossfire, we had no performance issues whatsover. We never saw a bug and had a completely solid experience. Xbox controls automapped to the xbox one controller.
